    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    To prevent these mistakes, adopt a strategy similar to the following example: Before making any counteroffer, 
    calculate its total value to you and compare it to your outside offer value. For instance, suppose you keep only [0, 0, 6, 0, 4] items and offer the rest to the other party. Your value would be:

    which is 426 (sum of all item values)
    
    which is less than your outside offer of 427. If your proposed offer results in a value lower than your outside offer, continue iterating until you develop a more advantageous offer that is better than your outside offer. 
    This reasoning can be applied to each of the five highlighted mistakes to ensure that your offers align with your objectives and avoid undesirable negotiation behaviors.

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    To prevent these mistakes, adopt a strategy similar to the following example: Before making any counteroffer, 
    calculate its total value to you and compare it to your outside offer value. For instance, suppose you keep only [3, 0, 0, 0, 0] items and offer the rest to the other party. Your value would be:
    8 x 3 + 56 x 0 + 67 x 0 + 33 x 0 + 36 x 0
    which is 24 (sum of all item values)
    
    which is less than your outside offer of 28. If your proposed offer results in a value lower than your outside offer, continue iterating until you develop a more advantageous offer that is better than your outside offer. 
    This reasoning can be applied to each of the five highlighted mistakes to ensure that your offers align with your objectives and avoid undesirable negotiation behaviors.

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    To prevent these mistakes, adopt a strategy similar to the following example: Before making any counteroffer, 
    calculate its total value to you and compare it to your outside offer value. For instance, suppose you keep only [0, 2, 2, 2, 5] items and offer the rest to the other party. Your value would be:
    27 x 0 + 32 x 2 + 79 x 2 + 6 x 2 + 70 x 5
    which is 584 (sum of all item values)
    
    which is less than your outside offer of 585. If your proposed offer results in a value lower than your outside offer, continue iterating until you develop a more advantageous offer that is better than your outside offer. 
    This reasoning can be applied to each of the five highlighted mistakes to ensure that your offers align with your objectives and avoid undesirable negotiation behaviors.

    Keep in mind the offers the opposing agent makes reflects its own values. If their offer includes most or all units of a particular item, it might indicate that the agent does not highly value that item, whereas offering none could suggest the opposite. 
    You can use this kind of evidence to help inform your decision-making.

round_data.response:
My outside offer guarantees me a payoff of 5. My own values (per unit) are very high compared to 5, so any deal in which I keep a substantial share of my high‐value items is far superior. I have a total of 4, 6, 3, 5, and 4 units across items 1–5 respectively and my values per unit are 85, 51, 4, 34, and 51. In a deal I want to keep as many units as possible from items I value highly (item 1, item 2, and item 5) while offering the opponent enough so that they prefer the deal over their own outside option (and to show some “fairness” so they will consider accepting rather than walking away).

For example, if I were to keep all units of the high‐value items I would obtain a value far above 5:
• If I keep all of item 1 (4×85 = 340), item 2 (6×51 = 306), item 4 (5×34 = 170), and item 5 (4×51 = 204), then even if I give away all of item 3 (which is only 4 per unit for me), my total would be 340 + 306 + 170 + 204 = 1020—huge compared to my fallback of 5.
However, if I offer nothing to the opponent they are unlikely to accept. It is therefore sensible to offer them some items that are either low in my value (or possibly high in their value) while I keep almost all of the high‐value items.

Item 3 is worth only 4 per unit to me. Thus, it makes sense to give the opponent all of item 3 (i.e. 3 units) because it hardly affects my outcome. For item 4, although I value it modestly, I can offer a few units (say 2) while keeping 3 for myself. For items 1, 2, and 5 (my higher‐value items), I want to give them as little as possible—in this case I choose to give the opponent 0 of item 1 and item 5, and possibly a minimal amount of item 2 (say 1 unit) so that the opponent receives something of tangible value.

Evaluating the outcome if I propose giving the opponent:
 • Item 1: 0 units (I keep 4 → 4×85 = 340)
 • Item 2: 1 unit (I keep 5 → 5×51 = 255)
 • Item 3: 3 units (I keep 0 → 0×4 = 0)
 • Item 4: 2 units (I keep 3 → 3×34 = 102)
 • Item 5: 0 units (I keep 4 → 4×51 = 204)

My total value from the items I keep is 340 + 255 + 0 + 102 + 204 = 901, which is far above my fallback of 5. This offer is very favorable to me while giving the opponent something to consider—and it avoids the mistakes of offering too little relative to my fallback or making a too generous offer on my high‐value items.

Thus, my action in round 1 is to propose a counteroffer with the offer [0, 1, 3, 2, 0].

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 1, 3, 2, 0]}

round_data.response:
My reasoning:
1. Our outside offer is 820. The current offer from Player 1 gives us [0,4,3,0,0] which yields a value of 0×99 + 4×33 + 3×88 + 0×6 + 0×55 = 396. This is far below our fallback of 820.
2. We need a counteroffer that, if accepted, nets us a total value higher than 820. We get a maximum value if we keep items with high per‐unit values. Item 1 (valued 99 per unit) and item 3 (valued 88 per unit) are most valuable to us, so we want to keep as many of these as possible.
3. The total pool is: [6,4,3,4,0]. If we give Player 1 nothing from items 1 and 3 and concede the less‐valuable items (items 2 and 4), we would keep all of item 1 and item 3. Keeping all of these gives us 6×99 + 3×88 = 594 + 264 = 858, which is better than our outside offer.
4. To propose a counteroffer, we can assign Player 1 all of items 2 and 4 while retaining all of items 1 and 3 for ourselves. The counteroffer (what we give to Player 1) is then [0,4,0,4,0]. This proposal yields us 858 without giving anything away from the items we most value, and it is clearly above our fallback.
5. Thus, the best move in round 1 is to propose the counteroffer: [0,4,0,4,0].

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0,4,0,4,0]}

Step-by-step reasoning:
1. Assessment of the current situation:
 • My outside offer value is 366.
 • The five items and their available quantities are: 
  – Item 1: 3 units (value per unit = 80)
  – Item 2: 5 units (value per unit = 6)
  – Item 3: 0 units (value per unit = 66)
  – Item 4: 3 units (value per unit = 14)
  – Item 5: 4 units (value per unit = 98)
 • The total “point” value if I got all items would be 704.
 • Being in round 1, there is no discount effect yet (γ^(round-1)=1); waiting or further rounds would reduce final payoffs.
 • Thus, any agreement I agree to must yield me a total value at least better than 366.

2. Assessing offers:
 • I want to maximize my outcome. My highest‐valued items are item 5 (98 per unit) and item 1 (80 per unit). The lower‐valued items for me are item 2 (6 per unit) and item 4 (14 per unit).
 • I aim not to give away too much of the items that matter most to me but at the same time want to make a credible offer to Player 2.
 • For example, if I kept all of item 1 and item 5, I’d get 3×80 + 4×98 = 240 + 392 = 632, which is well above 366. However, offering nothing of these might be seen as too aggressive and risk rejection.
 • As a balanced approach, I choose to give a small concession in the items that are valuable to Player 2. By offering 1 unit of Item 1 and 1 unit of Item 5, along with giving all of the lower‐value items (Item 2 and Item 4), I both secure my interests and make the deal more appealing to Player 2.
 • Under this proposal:
  – The offer to Player 2 is: 
   Item 1: 1 unit, Item 2: 5 units, Item 3: 0 units, Item 4: 3 units, Item 5: 1 unit.
  – That leaves me with:
   Item 1: 2 units, Item 2: 0 units, Item 3: 0 units, Item 4: 0 units, Item 5: 3 units.
 • My total value if the deal goes through:
  – From Item 1: 2 × 80 = 160
  – Item 5: 3 × 98 = 294
  – Total = 160 + 294 = 454, which is comfortably above my outside offer of 366.

3. Decision:
 • I am not accepting any current offer (since none exists) and I am not walking away.
 • I propose a counteroffer that both secures me a value above 366 and gives the other party some items that might be appealing (especially the full allotments of items 2 and 4, and a small portion of the high‐value items to soften my stance).

Thus, my action is to make the counteroffer with the proposed division.

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    To prevent these mistakes, adopt a strategy similar to the following example: Before making any counteroffer, 
    calculate its total value to you and compare it to your outside offer value. For instance, suppose you keep only [0, 1, 5, 0, 3] items and offer the rest to the other party. Your value would be:
    23 x 0 + 43 x 1 + 61 x 5 + 72 x 0 + 16 x 3
    which is 396 (sum of all item values)
    
    which is less than your outside offer of 397. If your proposed offer results in a value lower than your outside offer, continue iterating until you develop a more advantageous offer that is better than your outside offer. 
    This reasoning can be applied to each of the five highlighted mistakes to ensure that your offers align with your objectives and avoid undesirable negotiation behaviors.

    Keep in mind the offers the opposing agent makes reflects its own values. If their offer includes most or all units of a particular item, it might indicate that the agent does not highly value that item, whereas offering none could suggest the opposite. 
    You can use this kind of evidence to help inform your decision-making.

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    To prevent these mistakes, adopt a strategy similar to the following example: Before making any counteroffer, 
    calculate its total value to you and compare it to your outside offer value. For instance, suppose you keep only [1, 2, 7, 4, 5] items and offer the rest to the other party. Your value would be:
    54 x 1 + 30 x 2 + 18 x 7 + 15 x 4 + 98 x 5
    which is 790 (sum of all item values)
    
    which is less than your outside offer of 793. If your proposed offer results in a value lower than your outside offer, continue iterating until you develop a more advantageous offer that is better than your outside offer. 
    This reasoning can be applied to each of the five highlighted mistakes to ensure that your offers align with your objectives and avoid undesirable negotiation behaviors.

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    To prevent these mistakes, adopt a strategy similar to the following example: Before making any counteroffer, 
    calculate its total value to you and compare it to your outside offer value. For instance, suppose you keep only [4, 0, 5, 5, 7] items and offer the rest to the other party. Your value would be:

My reasoning:

1. Current situation:
 • My outside offer is 465.
 • My per‐unit values for items are: item1 = 41, item2 = 65, item3 = 89, item4 = 3, item5 = 58.
 • Total available items are: item1: 5, item2: 3, item3: 4, item4: 2, item5: 4.
 • In round 1 there is no discount (γ^0 = 1), so current and immediate outcomes do not suffer discounting. This means that if I wait, the potential value will be discounted in later rounds and I must aim for an offer that gives me a present value well above my outside offer (465).

2. Value assessment:
 • With any proposed offer, I will receive (Total – offered) units. I must ensure the value of my retained bundle exceeds 465.
 • For instance, if I propose to give Player 2 [2,1,1,2,1] units then I would retain:
  – Item1: 5–2 = 3 units → 3×41 = 123
  – Item2: 3–1 = 2 units → 2×65 = 130
  – Item3: 4–1 = 3 units → 3×89 = 267
  – Item4: 2–2 = 0 units → 0×3 = 0
  – Item5: 4–1 = 3 units → 3×58 = 174
  Total value = 123 + 130 + 267 + 0 + 174 = 694, comfortably above my outside offer.
 • This division avoids Mistake 2 (making myself worse off than my fallback) and does not “offer everything” (Mistake 3).

3. Final decision:
 • Since no offer is on the table yet, I propose my initial offer to give Player 2 [2,1,1,2,1] and keep the remainder for myself, ensuring my own total value of 694.
 • This offer is above my outside alternative and leaves me a strong fallback even if subsequent negotiations drive toward lower splits.
 • Therefore, I will propose this counteroffer.

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [2, 1, 1, 2, 1]}

    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    If a player chooses ACCEPT, the negotiation ends in a deal to divide the items according to the accepted offer.

    If a player chooses WALK, the negotiation ends without a deal, and each player receives the value of their private outside offer.

       - How do these values compare to my outside offer value?

    3) Make a decision based on the analysis:

       - Or should I propose a specific counteroffer?

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    To prevent these mistakes, adopt a strategy similar to the following example: Before making any counteroffer, 
    calculate its total value to you and compare it to your outside offer value. For instance, suppose you keep only [1, 5, 5, 3, 0] items and offer the rest to the other party. Your value would be:
    91 x 1 + 64 x 5 + 16 x 5 + 53 x 3 + 49 x 0
    which is 650 (sum of all item values)
    
    which is less than your outside offer of 651. If your proposed offer results in a value lower than your outside offer, continue iterating until you develop a more advantageous offer that is better than your outside offer. 
    This reasoning can be applied to each of the five highlighted mistakes to ensure that your offers align with your objectives and avoid undesirable negotiation behaviors.

    Keep in mind the offers the opposing agent makes reflects its own values. If their offer includes most or all units of a particular item, it might indicate that the agent does not highly value that item, whereas offering none could suggest the opposite.

round_data.response:
My outside offer is 651 (and if we reach an agreement in round 2 it will be discounted by 0.9, so to beat that I need a raw value of roughly 724 or higher). My private per‐unit values are [91, 64, 16, 53, 49] and the total available items are [2, 7, 5, 4, 3]. (If I got all items I would score 1069; clearly my goal is to secure a deal that gives me at least roughly 724 raw value so that after discount it exceeds 651.)

The current offer on the table (from Player 2) would give me [0, 0, 5, 0, 1] which calculates to a value of:
  item 1: 0 × 91 = 0  
  item 2: 0 × 64 = 0  
  item 3: 5 × 16 = 80  
  item 4: 0 × 53 = 0  
  item 5: 1 × 49 = 49  
Total = 129, which is far below my fallback of 651.

I therefore must propose a counteroffer that, when I keep the remainder of the items (i.e. total minus the offer), gives me a raw value of at least around 724. One attractive strategy is to concede items I value less (for instance, item 3, which is only 16 per unit) while keeping nearly all of the high‐value items. My earlier proposal in round 1 was to offer Player 2 all of item 3 (i.e. [0, 0, 5, 0, 0]), which would yield me a keep of [2, 7, 0, 4, 3] and a raw value of:  
  2×91 + 7×64 + 0×16 + 4×53 + 3×49 = 182 + 448 + 0 + 212 + 147 = 989.  
That is well above the threshold—but Player 2’s counteroffer in round 1 ([0,0,5,0,1]) suggests they might be aiming for a bit more concession on another item (they gave me an extra unit of item 5 compared to my first offer).

To potentially improve the chance for an acceptable deal without sacrificing too much, I can make a slight concession on another item. For example, by offering Player 2 one unit of item 2 as well as the full amount of item 3, and one unit of item 5 (as in their offer), the counteroffer becomes [0, 1, 5, 0, 1]. Under that offer my allocation becomes:  
  item 1: 2–0 = 2 units → 2×91 = 182  
  item 2: 7–1 = 6 units → 6×64 = 384  
  item 3: 5–5 = 0 units → 0×16 = 0  
  item 4: 4–0 = 4 units → 4×53 = 212  
  item 5: 3–1 = 2 units → 2×49 = 98  
Total = 182 + 384 + 0 + 212 + 98 = 886,  
which comfortably exceeds the needed raw value threshold (886 × 0.9 ≈ 797 > 651).

This counteroffer avoids the mistakes of offering me a value lower than my fallback and is an improvement over the current offer relative to my objectives.

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0,1,5,0,1]}

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

Step-by-step reasoning:
1. My outside offer value is 245. This is the guaranteed outcome if I choose to WALK.
2. My private value per unit is: item 1 = 13, item 2 = 35, item 3 = 28, item 4 = 3, item 5 = 28.
3. The full pool is: item 1: 2 units, item 2: 2 units, item 3: 7 units, item 4: 2 units, item 5: 3 units.
4. In round 3, the discount factor is gamma = 0.9. For outcomes reached in round 3, the deal’s value is multiplied by gamma^(3–1) = 0.9² = 0.81, so any outcomes are effectively worth 81% of their undiscounted value.
5. The current offer on the table awards me [1, 1, 1, 0, 0]. Its undiscounted value is:
  Item 1: 1 x 13 = 13
  Item 2: 1 x 35 = 35
  Item 3: 1 x 28 = 28
  Item 4: 0 x 3 = 0
  Item 5: 0 x 28 = 0
  Total undiscounted value = 13 + 35 + 28 = 76.
6. Applying the round 3 discount, the present-value of this offer is 76 x 0.81 ≈ 61.56.
7. Comparing offers, 61.56 (discounted current offer) is far less than my outside offer of 245.
8. Since it is round 3, and any counteroffer would be treated as WALK, my best option is not to accept the poor current deal and instead WALK away to secure the outside offer of 245.

Final answer:
{"action": "WALK"}

 Item 1: 5 × 81 = 405  
 Item 2: 4 × 6 = 24  
 Item 3: 3 × 57 = 171  
 Item 4: 5 × 20 = 100  
 Item 5: 1 × 68 = 68  
 Total = 768  

The current offer gives me [0, 0, 3, 0, 1] which is:  
 Item 3: 3 × 57 = 171  
 Item 5: 1 × 68 = 68  
 Total = 239, which is much lower than my outside offer.  

To beat my fallback of 764, I need a deal where my share (the items I keep) is worth at least 765. Because giving even 1 unit of any item drops my value by at least 6 (the smallest loss is 6 from item 2), any concession would lower my total below 764. In fact, if I give away any item (even one unit of item 2), my value would drop from 768 to at most 762, which is worse than taking my outside offer.  

Thus, to secure more than my fallback, my only safe option is to propose the division where I get all items (768). In our counteroffer format, that means offering Player 1 nothing: [0, 0, 0, 0, 0]. While offering nothing is generally cautioned against as a suboptimal negotiating behavior (Mistake 3), here it is the only way to ensure my negotiated deal exceeds my outside offer of 764.

Therefore, my action is to make the following counteroffer:

round_data.response:
My analysis is as follows:

1. My outside offer guarantees me 149 in value. Accepting the current offer of [0, 0, 0, 0, 1] would yield only 59 value (1 unit of item 5 × 59) which is far below my fallback. Therefore, I must do better.

2. I can propose a counteroffer. In a counteroffer I specify the items I give to Player 1; what I keep is the remainder. My private values are: item1 = 27, item2 = 41, item3 = 54, item4 = 10, and item5 = 59. The total items available are: [7, 2, 4, 5, 4].

3. I want to ensure that the outcome I get (what I keep) far exceeds my outside offer. For example, consider offering Player 1:
 • 1 unit of item 1 (giving me 6 units),
 • 0 units of item 2 (keeping all 2),
 • 0 units of item 3 (keeping all 4),
 • all 5 units of item 4 (since I value item 4 the least),
 • and 1 unit of item 5 (keeping 3 units).
 This means I would keep: [6, 2, 4, 0, 3].

4. My value for the kept bundle is:
 • Item 1: 6 × 27 = 162
 • Item 2: 2 × 41 = 82
 • Item 3: 4 × 54 = 216
 • Item 4: 0 × 10 = 0
 • Item 5: 3 × 59 = 177
 Total = 162 + 82 + 216 + 0 + 177 = 637, which is well above my outside offer of 149.

5. This counteroffer avoids the mistakes of accepting a deal worse than my fallback and keeps my retained value high while conceding items (especially item 4) that I value relatively little. 

Thus, my action is to produce a counteroffer with the offer array [1, 0, 0, 5, 1].

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 0, 0, 5, 1]}

    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    To prevent these mistakes, adopt a strategy similar to the following example: Before making any counteroffer,

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    To prevent these mistakes, adopt a strategy similar to the following example: Before making any counteroffer, 
    calculate its total value to you and compare it to your outside offer value. For instance, suppose you keep only [0, 1, 3, 0, 1] items and offer the rest to the other party. Your value would be:
    84 x 0 + 50 x 1 + 14 x 3 + 55 x 0 + 100 x 1
    which is 192 (sum of all item values)
    
    which is less than your outside offer of 193. If your proposed offer results in a value lower than your outside offer, continue iterating until you develop a more advantageous offer that is better than your outside offer. 
    This reasoning can be applied to each of the five highlighted mistakes to ensure that your offers align with your objectives and avoid undesirable negotiation behaviors.

    Keep in mind the offers the opposing agent makes reflects its own values. If their offer includes most or all units of a particular item, it might indicate that the agent does not highly value that item, whereas offering none could suggest the opposite. 
    You can use this kind of evidence to help inform your decision-making.

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

round_data.response:
My reasoning is as follows:

1) Situation overview:
• My outside offer is worth 110.
• My per‐unit values are: item1 = 11, item2 = 32, item3 = 4, item4 = 92, and item5 = 20.
• The full pool has: 4 units of item1, 2 units of item2, 6 units of item3, 3 units of item4, and 2 units of item5.
• Because this is round 1 there is no discount (gamma^(0)=1); however, if we waited later the overall values would be discounted, so it is better to secure a high value now.
• I need to ensure that what I retain is worth more than my fallback (110), and in designing my offer I must avoid mistakes like offering myself less than my outside offer value or giving too much away without reason.

2) Offer evaluation:
• I want to claim the items I value highly (especially item4 at 92 per unit) and concede some of the lower value items.
• For example, if I retain 3 units of item1, 1 unit of item2, 4 units of item3, all 3 units of item4, and both units of item5, my total value is:
  3×11 = 33,
  1×32 = 32,
  4×4 = 16,
  3×92 = 276,
  2×20 = 40,
  Total = 33+32+16+276+40 = 397, which is well above my outside offer.
• To achieve this, knowing the full pool, I would allocate to myself:
  item1: 3 (thus offer 1),
  item2: 1 (offer 1),
  item3: 4 (offer 2),
  item4: 3 (offer 0),
  item5: 2 (offer 0).

3) Decision:
• My retained value of 397 is far superior to the fallback of 110.
• This division minimizes concessions (offering fewer units where my value is high) and gives up only a small amount of the lower valued items (item1, item2, and item3).
• There is no current offer to accept, so I will now propose this counteroffer.

Thus, my action is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 1, 2, 0, 0]}

which lets me keep a value of 1453 for myself. This meets my objective of a deal significantly better than my outside offer.

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    To prevent these mistakes, adopt a strategy similar to the following example: Before making any counteroffer,

    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.

    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    To prevent these mistakes, adopt a strategy similar to the following example: Before making any counteroffer, 
    calculate its total value to you and compare it to your outside offer value. For instance, suppose you keep only [3, 3, 1, 4, 1] items and offer the rest to the other party. Your value would be:

    which is 491 (sum of all item values)
    
    which is less than your outside offer of 492. If your proposed offer results in a value lower than your outside offer, continue iterating until you develop a more advantageous offer that is better than your outside offer.

    In the bargaining game, there are five mistakes you can make that conflict with your objectives. 
    While these aren't the only possible errors, they represent undesirable negotiation behaviors that can undermine your payoff or cause you to miss out on better deals. 
    These mistakes are:
    - Mistake 1: Making an offer worse than your previous offer. This occurs when you reject an offer better for you than the one you subsequently propose. 
    - Mistake 2: Making an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This happens if you propose giving away so much that what you keep is worth less than your guaranteed alternative, which is your outside offer.
    - Mistake 3: Offering no items or all items. Offering nothing (or everything) to the opponent (in the early or middle rounds) can be a clear suboptimal move. 
    - Mistake 4: Accepting an offer worse for you than your outside offer. This occurs if you accept a division that yields a payoff lower than your guaranteed fallback.
    - Mistake 5: Walking away from an offer better than your outside offer. This occurs when you reject a division that actually yields a higher payoff than your fallback.

    To prevent these mistakes, adopt a strategy similar to the following example: Before making any counteroffer, 
    calculate its total value to you and compare it to your outside offer value. For instance, suppose you keep only [2, 0, 3, 0, 1] items and offer the rest to the other party. Your value would be:
    49 x 2 + 20 x 0 + 30 x 3 + 67 x 0 + 56 x 1
    which is 244 (sum of all item values)
    
    which is less than your outside offer of 246. If your proposed offer results in a value lower than your outside offer, continue iterating until you develop a more advantageous offer that is better than your outside offer. 
    This reasoning can be applied to each of the five highlighted mistakes to ensure that your offers align with your objectives and avoid undesirable negotiation behaviors.

    Keep in mind the offers the opposing agent makes reflects its own values. If their offer includes most or all units of a particular item, it might indicate that the agent does not highly value that item, whereas offering none could suggest the opposite. 
    You can use this kind of evidence to help inform your decision-making.
